title: Matsumoto Kaidō
text:
The , also known as the , the or simply as the was a <a href="Hime%20kaid%C5%8D">secondary road</a> in pre-modern <a href="Japan">Japan</a>, connecting <a href="Matsumoto%2C%20Nagano">Matsumoto</a> in <a href="Shinano%20Province">Shinano Province</a> with <a href="Itoigawa%2C%20Niigata">Itoigawa</a> in <a href="Echigo%20Province">Echigo Province</a>). In the year 2002, a well-preserved 20-kilometer section of the original path in the city of Itoigawa was designated a <a href="Monuments%20of%20Japan">National Historic Site of Japan</a>, and an additional 10-kilometer section was added in 2007.
Overview.
The Matsumoto Kaidō was a steep mountain trail following the <a href="Hime%20River">Himekawa River</a> valley, about 120 kilometers in length, and has been in existence since very ancient times, as evidenced by <a href="J%C5%8Dmon%20period">Jōmon period</a> <a href="jade">jade</a> beads and <a href="jadeite">jadeite</a> <a href="stone%20axe">stone axe</a>s produced in the Itoigawa area found at archaeological sites in the <a href="Kant%C5%8D%20region">Kantō region</a> of Japan. The road was used for the transport of salt and preserved seafood from the <a href="Sea%20of%20Japan">Sea of Japan</a> to inland regions, and for the export of soybeans, tobacco, herbal medicines, cotton, hemp and livestock from Shinano Province and the Kantō region. The standard method of travel was by foot, as wheeled carts were almost nonexistent and the road was too steep in most places. The route was also frequently closed due to heavy snowfall, avalanches, landslides, and flooding.
Salt was a critical commodity in pre-modern Japan, and the <a href="Sengoku%20period">Sengoku period</a> warlord <a href="Uesugi%20Kenshin">Uesugi Kenshin</a> was famous for abolishing taxes on salt and allowing it to be exported to his enemy, <a href="Takada%20Shingen">Takada Shingen</a>, both as a gesture of magnanimity and also to remove a possible "<a href="casus%20belli">casus belli</a>". The salt trade came to be monopolized by six merchant houses from Shinano, who received official permits from the <a href="Tokugawa%20shogunate">Tokugawa shogunate</a> in 1604. Pack horses and cows were used to transport loads at an average pace of 30 kilometers per day. During the <a href="Edo%20period">Edo period</a>, as no "<a href="daimy%C5%8D">daimyō</a>" processions used the route for "<a href="sankin-k%C5%8Dtai">sankin-kōtai</a>", no formal system of <a href="shukuba">post stations</a> with "<a href="honjin">honjin</a>" was established. However, there were numerous checkpoints where domain officials examined travel permits and cargos, levied taxes, and at which were located small shops whose exorbitant prices and lack of goods was a perennial complaint by travellers. The checkpoints were removed after the <a href="Meiji%20restoration">Meiji restoration</a> in 1867.
After the start of the <a href="Meiji%20period">Meiji period</a>, the opening of the <a href="Shin%27etsu%20Main%20Line">Shin'etsu Main Line</a> and the <a href="%C5%8Cito%20Line">Ōito Line</a> railways, and later <a href="Japan%20National%20Route%20147">Japan National Route 147</a> / <a href="Japan%20National%20Route%20148">Japan National Route 148</a> eliminated the need for this road by 1892, and it gradually fell into ruin, although portions continued to be used as forestry roads and by local inhabitants. The city of Itoigawa maintains a museu, the with historical materials on the route.
